MainClaim.text: "Shifting focus to Mendelssohn's conception of enlightenment acknowledges the importance of diverse forms of historically female intellectuality and sociality

Untitled1.text: "Mendelssohn's conception of enlightenment has a distinctively inclusive character

Untitled2.text: "Mendelssohn's conception of enlightenment emphasizes the importance of diverse forms of historically female intellectuality and sociality."

Untitled3.text: "Women actively engaged with and critically evaluated Mendelssohn's views on enlightenment

Untitled4.text: "Herz's and Varnhagen's efforts to expand women's role in promoting the flourishing of culture served to test and revise the boundaries between the sexes."

Untitled5.text: "Holst's attempts to realize the emancipatory potential in the notion of the vocation of a human being as a human being furnished it with an appropriately ambitious theory of education."

Untitled6.text: "Reimarus' forthright account of the responsibility of the would-be enlightener to gradually but decisively persist in undermining the edifice of prejudice that stands in the way of enlightenment."

Untitled7.text: "Mendelssohn's conception of enlightenment is inclusive of women in spite of its considerable virtue."

Untitled8.text: "Mendelssohn's conception of enlightenment has been neglected by historians of philosophy and of the Enlightenment in spite of its considerable virtue."

Untitled9.text: "The conception of enlightenment framed by Mendelssohn

Untitled10.text: "Holst's *Über die Bestimmung des Weibes zur höhern Geistesbildung* of 1802 makes the case for women's right to education in terms familiar from Mendelssohn's essay on enlightenment."

Untitled11.text: "Reimarus' views on the advance of enlightenment are distinct from Mendelssohn's more concessive approach."

Untitled12.text: "Reimarus' views on the advance of enlightenment are characterized by a cautious but persistent advancement."

Untitled13.text: "Reimarus' views on the advance of enlightenment are influenced by her engagement with Mendelssohn."

Untitled14.text: "Mendelssohn's conception of enlightenment emphasizes the importance of education for cultivating the child's intellect and will."

Untitled15.text: "Mendelssohn's conception of enlightenment is distinct from Kant's conception of enlightenment."
